ã€Treatiseã€‘ Question:
If the world is free from the three poisons and also free from the names of the three poisons, for what purpose did the Buddha appear in that country?
Answer:
Greed, anger, and delusion are called the three unwholesome roots, which are dharmas bound to the desire realm.
If the Buddha speaks of greed, anger, and delusion, they are unwholesome dharmas bound to the desire realm;
If he speaks of defiled attachment and ignorance, then they pervade the three realms.
There are buddha-realms where people are purely attached to desires. For the sake of these beings, bodhisattvas vow:
When I attain buddhahood, my land will be free from the three poisons and even the names of the three poisons.

There are also pure buddha lands where only non-regressing bodhisattvas with bodies born from the Dharma-nature reside. They are free from afflictions but still have residual habits. Therefore, it is said that there are no names for the three poisons.
If someone says:
Just as bodhisattvas vow to deliver all beings, yet beings are not actually all delivered;
This is also like that. If one wishes for a world free from the names of the three poisons, there should actually be three poisons that are not exhausted.
If there are no three poisons, what use is there for a buddha?
Just as if there were no great darkness on the ground, then the sun would not be needed to shine.
As it is said in the sutra:
If there were no three dharmas, then a buddha would not appear in the world. If the three dharmas were not severed, then one would not attain freedom from old age, sickness, and death.
Three dharmas refers to the three poisons, as in the Sutra on the Three Dharmas, which should be explained in detail here.
Furthermore, there are worlds where sentient beings discriminate dharmas as good or bad, bound or liberated, and so forth, giving rise to idle speculation within the dharma of one-sided quiescence;
Therefore, the bodhisattva vows,
May the sentient beings in my world not give rise to the three poisons, but know that the true nature of the three poisons is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a.

Answer:
Wisdom is the right view of the world.
In the right view of the world, it is said that there is giving, there are sins and blessings, there is this world and the next world, and there are arhats.
Because one believes in sins and blessings, one is able to give generously.
Because one believes in the existence of arhats, one is able to uphold precepts well, cultivate meditation well, and practice pure conduct well.
Because of the power of right view, one is able to skillfully not disturb sentient beings.
Right view in the world is the root of uncontaminated wisdom. For this reason, it is said that in the country there is no mention of the three poisons.
There are two kinds of greed:
first, wrong greed, and second, greed.
There are two kinds of hatred:
first, wrong hatred, and second, hatred.
There are two kinds of delusion:

These three kinds of wrong poisons are difficult to transform and liberate sentient beings, while the other three are easy to liberate.
No mention of the three poisons means there is no mention of the three wrong poisons.
The five matters such as good giving are as explained above in the chapter on emitting light.

This is the true nature of dharmas, which is unborn and unceasing, neither annihilated nor eternal, neither identical nor different, neither coming nor going, neither grasped nor moved, neither attached to nor dependent, and non-existent, like the nature of nirvana.
If the nature of dharmas is like this, how can there be cessation?
Question:

As you say, the true nature of dharmas is without cessation.
There are people who imagine and discriminate, grasping the characteristics of dharmas and destroying the true nature of dharmas, using two dharmas to explain, and therefore there is cessation;

It has already been said that there are two kinds of Buddhas:
The first is the Buddha born from the Dharma-nature, and the second is the Buddha who manifests according to the superiority and inferiority of sentient beings.
For the sake of the Dharma-nature born body Buddha, it is said that even hearing the name can lead to liberation;

For the sake of the Buddha who manifests according to the capacities of sentient beings, it is said that although one may dwell with the Buddha, due to karmic causes and conditions, there are those who fall into hell.
The Dharma-nature born body Buddha has no affairs that are not accomplished and no wishes that are not fulfilled.
Why is this so?

For immeasurable and incalculable eons, he has accumulated all wholesome roots and merits, all wisdom is unobstructed and complete, and he is the lord of the multitude of sages. The devas and great bodhisattvas rarely have the opportunity to see him.
It is like the wish-fulfilling jewel which is difficult to see and obtain. If there are those who see it, their wishes will surely be fulfilled.

It is like those who think of AvalokitÃªÅ›vara Bodhisattva's name, all escaping from misfortune and danger.

If one's mind is like this, how can one be saved?

For this reason, it is said:

Furthermore, hearing the name does not mean attaining the Way merely by the name;

Answer:
Now it is said immediately, not in one thought;

It is like a ripe boil that, if not treated by a doctor, will burst on its own due to a slight cause.

It is for the sake of such people that it is said that if they hear the Buddha's name, they will immediately attain the Way.
